prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Management of transferred cases—Supervision by the Panel

para.paratext: Because the Panel is not involved in the management of cases once transferred, there are no specific rules for handling transferred cases. In practice, cases that qualify for transfer under the statute will be suitable for treatment under some of the procedures established in the Manual for Complex Litigation (“Manual”).[1] The Panel has approved the use of the Manual in transferred cases, and has even expressed its preference that Manual procedures be implemented by the transferee court.[2] The fact that a case has been transferred does not change the operation of the rules or result in the abrogation of a litigants rights. In one case the appellate court held, for example, that MDL transfer did not change the traditional rules favoring liberal amendment of pleadings.[3]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See Manual for Complex Litigation Fourth (2004).

See, e.g., In re South Cent. States Bakery Products Antitrust Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1127, 1130 (J.P.M.L. 1977) (use of previously taken discovery); In re Ascot Oils, Inc. Securities Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1118, 1120 (J.P.M.L. 1977) (lead and liaison counsel and minimization of discovery expense on noncommon issues).
See In re Korean Air Lines Co., 642 F.3d 685 (9th Cir. 2011). See alsoIn re Caterpillar Inc., 67 F. Supp. 3d 663 (D.N.J. 2014).
